stem:
A 28-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain for 12 hours. She 
ran out of insulin 2 days ago. On examination, she is lethargic but arousable. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 92/58 mm Hg, pulse is 
118/min, and respirations are 26/min with deep, labored breathing. Mucous membranes are dry, and skin turgor is decreased. 
Laboratory studies show: 
• 
Serum glucose: 486 mg/dL 
• 
Serum sodium: 131 mEq/L 
• 
Serum potassium: 5.4 mEq/L 
• 
Serum bicarbonate: 10 mEq/L 
• 
BUN: 38 mg/dL 
• 
Creatinine: 1.6 mg/dL 
• 
Arterial pH: 7.18 
• 
Serum ketones: positive

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

options.text: Intravenous regular insulin bolus followed by continuous infusion
options.label: A

explanation: This patient presents with classic DKA: hyperglycemia (>250 mg/dL), anion gap metabolic acidosis (pH <7.30, bicarbonate <18), and ketonemia. The critical initial management decision is fluid resuscitation before insulin. Why fluids first? • DKA causes profound volume depletion (average deficit 5–7 L) due to osmotic diuresis • Hypotension and tachycardia indicate hemodynamic compromise requiring immediate volume expansion • Insulin administration before adequate fluid resuscitation can precipitate cardiovascular collapse and hypokalemia • Initial NS bolus (15–20 mL/kg/hr or 1–1.5 L in first hour) restores perfusion Why not insulin first (A, D)? • Insulin drives potassium intracellularly; giving insulin before confirming adequate potassium (>3.3 mEq/L) and before fluid resuscitation risks fatal arrhythmia • This patient's potassium of 5.4 mEq/L is falsely elevated due to acidosis — total body potassium is depleted Why not bicarbonate (C)? • Bicarbonate is reserved for pH <6.9 or severe hyperkalemia with ECG changes • Routine bicarbonate worsens intracellular acidosis and delays ketone clearance Why not potassium first (E)? • Potassium is 5.4 mEq/L (>5.2); potassium replacement begins once K+ falls below 5.2 mEq/L during treatment Clinical pearl: The sequence in DKA is: Fluids → Potassium assessment → Insulin. This order reduces mortality.

stem:
A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her family for confusion and agitation. She has a history of Graves disease but 
stopped taking her methimazole 3 weeks ago. Yesterday she developed fever, diarrhea, and palpitations. Today she became disoriented and combative. 
On examination, temperature is 39.8°C (103.6°F), blood pressure is 168/70 mm Hg, pulse is 152/min and irregularly irregular, and respirations are 24/min. 
She is diaphoretic with a fine tremor, lid lag, and diffuse thyroid enlargement. 
Laboratory studies show: 
• 
TSH: <0.01 mIU/L 
• 
Free T4: 6.8 ng/dL (normal 0.8–1.8) 
• 
Free T3: 892 pg/dL (normal 230–420) 
ECG shows atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

In addition to supportive care and cooling measures, which of the following is the most appropriate FIRST pharmacologic intervention?
explanation: This patient has thyroid storm (Burch-Wartofsky score would be >45), a life-threatening exacerbation of hyperthyroidism characterized by: • Fever (>39°C) • CNS dysfunction (confusion, agitation) • Cardiovascular compromise (tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, widened pulse pressure) • GI symptoms (diarrhea) • Precipitating event (medication discontinuation) Treatment sequence matters: 1. Beta-blocker FIRST (Propranolol) • Controls life-threatening sympathetic hyperactivity • Propranolol specifically also inhibits peripheral T4→T3 conversion • Addresses immediate mortality risk from arrhythmia and cardiovascular collapse • Must be given before iodine to prevent iodine from fueling further hormone synthesis 2. Thionamide (PTU preferred in storm) • Blocks new hormone synthesis • PTU also inhibits peripheral T4→T3 conversion • Given after beta-blockade is initiated 3. Iodine (Lugol's or SSKI) — given 1 hour AFTER thionamide • Blocks hormone release (Wolff-Chaikoff effect) • Must wait until thionamide has blocked synthesis; otherwise iodine provides substrate for more hormone production 4. Glucocorticoids • Block peripheral T4→T3 conversion • Treat potential concurrent adrenal insufficiency • Given as adjunct, not first-line Why not (A) PTU first? • While essential, it does not address immediate cardiovascular crisis • Beta-blockade provides faster symptomatic control Why not (C) Iodine first? • Giving iodine before thionamide can worsen thyrotoxicosis (Jod-Basedow phenomenon) Why not (E)? • Radioactive iodine is contraindicated in thyroid storm — would release preformed hormone

stem:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a 4-month history of progressive fatigue, 7-kg (15-lb) unintentional weight loss, and intermittent nausea. 
She also reports light-headedness when standing. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. 

On examination, blood pressure is 94/62 mm Hg supine and 78/50 mm Hg standing with pulse increasing from 72 to 98/min. Hyperpigmentation is 
noted on the palmar creases, buccal mucosa, and a recent surgical scar. 
Laboratory studies show: 
• 
Serum sodium: 128 mEq/L 
• 
Serum potassium: 5.8 mEq/L 
• 
Fasting glucose: 64 mg/dL 
• 
Morning cortisol: 2.1 µg/dL (normal 5–25) 
• 
ACTH: 892 pg/mL (normal 10–60)

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: This patient presents with classic features of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease): Clinical features: • Fatigue, weight loss, nausea (chronic glucocorticoid deficiency) • Orthostatic hypotension (mineralocorticoid deficiency → salt wasting) • Hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed and pressure areas (elevated ACTH stimulates melanocortin receptors) Laboratory findings supporting primary adrenal insufficiency: • Hyponatremia (mineralocorticoid deficiency) • Hyperkalemia (aldosterone deficiency) • Hypoglycemia (cortisol deficiency) • Low morning cortisol (<5 µg/dL is highly suggestive) • Elevated ACTH (confirms primary, not secondary) Confirmatory test: The cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test is the gold standard: • 250 µg synthetic ACTH given IV/IM • Cortisol measured at 30 and 60 minutes • Normal response: cortisol ≥18–20 µg/dL • Failure to rise confirms adrenal insufficiency Why not other options? (A) 24-hour urine free cortisol — Used to diagnose Cushing syndrome (cortisol excess), not deficiency (B) Dexamethasone suppression test — Also for Cushing syndrome workup (D) CT of adrenal glands — May be done after biochemical confirmation to identify etiology (autoimmune, hemorrhage, infection, metastasis) but is not the confirmatory diagnostic test (E) Adrenal vein sampling — Used in primary hyperaldosteronism workup to lateralize adenoma After confirmation: Most common cause in developed countries is autoimmune adrenalitis (check 21-hydroxylase antibodies). Start glucocorticoid (hydrocortisone) and mineralocorticoid (fludrocortisone) replacement.

stem:
A 72-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department from a nursing home with altered mental status. Staff report 
he has had decreased oral intake and increasing lethargy over the past week following a urinary tract infection treated with antibiotics. 
On examination, he is obtunded and responds only to painful stimuli. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 88/52 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, 
and respirations are 18/min. Mucous membranes are severely dry, and skin tenting is present. 
Laboratory studies show: 
• 
Serum glucose: 928 mg/dL 
• 
Serum sodium: 149 mEq/L (corrected: 162 mEq/L) 
• 
Serum potassium: 4.8 mEq/L 
• 
Serum bicarbonate: 21 mEq/L 
• 
BUN: 68 mg/dL 
• 
Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL 
• 
Arterial pH: 7.32 
• 
Serum osmolality: 384 mOsm/kg 
• 
Serum ketones: trace 
• 
Urine: positive for bacteria and WBCs

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
explanation: This patient has Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS), distinguished from DKA by: Feature HHS DKA Glucose >600 mg/dL (often >1000) >250 mg/dL Osmolality >320 mOsm/kg Variable pH >7.30 <7.30 Bicarbonate >18 mEq/L <18 mEq/L Feature HHS DKA Ketones Absent/trace Moderate-large Mental status Often severely altered Variable Key management principles: 1. Aggressive fluid resuscitation is the FIRST priority • HHS patients have more profound volume depletion than DKA (average 8–10 L deficit vs 5–7 L) • Start with isotonic saline (0.9% NS) regardless of sodium level • Initial rate: 1–1.5 L in first hour • This patient is hypotensive — isotonic fluid is essential to restore intravascular volume 2. Switch to hypotonic saline (0.45%) AFTER: • Hemodynamic stability is achieved • Corrected sodium is evaluated (if elevated, use 0.45% NS; if low/normal, continue 0.9% NS) Why not (A) insulin bolus? • Fluid resuscitation alone will lower glucose significantly in HHS • Insulin is started at lower doses (0.025–0.05 units/kg/hr) and only after initial fluids • Rapid glucose correction risks cerebral edema Why not (B) 0.45% saline? • Hypotonic saline is inappropriate initial therapy in hypotensive patients • Need isotonic fluid first to restore perfusion Why not (D) D5 with 0.45% NS? • Dextrose-containing fluids are added later when glucose reaches 250–300 mg/dL • Not appropriate initially with glucose of 928 mg/dL Mortality in HHS (10–20%) exceeds DKA (1–5%) — often due to delayed recognition, underlying precipitant (infection, MI), and thromboembolic complications.

stem:
A 38-year-old woman is evaluated for episodes of severe headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis occurring several times per week for the past 3 months. 
During these episodes, she feels intense anxiety and her face becomes flushed. Her blood pressure between episodes is 142/92 mm Hg. Family history is 
notable for a brother who had thyroid cancer. 

Evaluation reveals elevated 24-hour urine catecholamines and metanephrines. CT of the abdomen shows a 4.2-cm right adrenal mass with high 
attenuation.

Surgical resection is planned. Which of the following is the most appropriate preoperative management?

options.text: Proceed directly to surgery without pharmacologic preparation
options.label: E

explanation: This patient has classic pheochromocytoma — episodic catecholamine release causing the triad of: • Headache • Palpitations • Diaphoresis (+ hypertension) The family history of thyroid cancer raises concern for MEN2 syndrome (medullary thyroid cancer + pheochromocytoma ± hyperparathyroidism). Preoperative alpha-blockade is MANDATORY before surgery: Why alpha-blockade FIRST (phenoxybenzamine)? • Blocks α1 receptors → vasodilation → controls hypertension • Allows intravascular volume expansion (catecholamine-induced vasoconstriction causes chronic volume contraction) • Prevents intraoperative hypertensive crisis during tumor manipulation • Started 10–14 days before surgery; liberal salt/fluid intake encouraged Why beta-blockade SECOND? • Beta-blockade controls reflex tachycardia that occurs after alpha-blockade • NEVER give beta-blockers before alpha-blockade — this causes unopposed alpha stimulation → severe hypertensive crisis • Typically added 2–3 days after alpha-blockade is established Why not (A)? • Propranolol (beta-blocker) before alpha-blockade is dangerous • Allows unopposed alpha-adrenergic vasoconstriction → hypertensive emergency Why not (C) propranolol alone? • Same rationale — no alpha coverage leads to crisis Why not (D) labetalol alone? • Labetalol has both alpha and beta effects, but beta effects predominate • Not reliable for adequate alpha-blockade in pheochromocytoma Why not (E)? • Surgery without preoperative blockade has historically high mortality from intraoperative hypertensive crisis, arrhythmias, and cardiovascular collapse Metyrosine (inhibits catecholamine synthesis) is sometimes added in refractory cases.

stem:
A 68-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter who found her minimally responsive at home. The daughter reports her 
mother has seemed increasingly confused and lethargic over the past 2 weeks. The patient has a history of hypothyroidism but has not been taking her 
levothyroxine for "several months." 
On examination, the patient is obtunded. Temperature is 34.2°C (93.6°F), blood pressure is 88/58 mm Hg, pulse is 48/min, and respirations are 8/min. She 
has periorbital edema, macroglossia, dry coarse skin, and delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes. 
Laboratory studies show: 
• 
TSH: 89 mIU/L (normal 0.5–4.5) 
• 
Free T4: <0.2 ng/dL (normal 0.8–1.8) 
• 
Serum sodium: 118 mEq/L 
• 
Serum glucose: 52 mg/dL 
• 
Serum cortisol: 8 µg/dL 
In addition to supportive care including warming and airway management, which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic

treatment?
explanation: This patient has myxedema coma, a life-threatening decompensation of severe hypothyroidism characterized by: • Altered mental status (cardinal feature) • Hypothermia • Bradycardia • Hypotension • Hypoventilation • Hyponatremia (impaired free water excretion) • Hypoglycemia Treatment must address two critical issues: 1. Thyroid hormone replacement (IV levothyroxine) • Oral absorption is unreliable in critically ill patients • Loading dose: 200–400 µg IV, then 50–100 µg/day • Some protocols add IV T3 (liothyronine) for faster onset 2. Glucocorticoid coverage (IV hydrocortisone) — CRITICAL • Severe hypothyroidism impairs adrenal function • Additionally, thyroid hormone replacement increases cortisol metabolism • Starting levothyroxine without glucocorticoids can precipitate adrenal crisis • Give hydrocortisone 100 mg IV, then 50–100 mg q8h until adrenal function confirmed Why must steroids be given with thyroid hormone? • Hypothyroidism reduces cortisol clearance, masking underlying adrenal insufficiency • Giving T4 alone accelerates cortisol metabolism → relative adrenal insufficiency → cardiovascular collapse Why not (A)? • Oral administration is inappropriate in obtunded patient with GI hypomotility Why not (B)? • Missing the crucial glucocorticoid coverage Why not (D)? • T3 alone without T4 provides no sustained hormone levels • T3 may be added as adjunct to T4, not as sole therapy Precipitants to identify: infection (most common), cold exposure, sedatives, surgery, trauma Mortality remains 30–60% even with treatment — emphasizes the emergency nature.

stem:
A 52-year-old man is hospitalized following surgical clipping of a ruptured intracranial aneurysm 5 days ago. He initially did well postoperatively but now 
has mild confusion. 
Vital signs show blood pressure 108/68 mm Hg (baseline 132/84), pulse 98/min, and temperature 37.0°C. Physical examination reveals dry mucous 
membranes and flat neck veins. Skin turgor is mildly decreased. 

Laboratory studies show: 
• 
Serum sodium: 124 mEq/L 
• 
Serum osmolality: 258 mOsm/kg 
• 
Urine sodium: 85 mEq/L 
• 
Urine osmolality: 420 mOsm/kg 
• 
BUN: 28 mg/dL 
• 
Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL 
• 
Uric acid: 2.1 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

options.text: Oral salt tablets with fluid restriction
options.label: D

explanation: This patient has hyponatremia in the setting of neurosurgery — the differential includes SIADH and cerebral salt wasting (CSW). Both share: • Hypotonic hyponatremia • Inappropriately concentrated urine (osmolality >100) • Elevated urine sodium (>40 mEq/L) • Low serum uric acid The KEY differentiator is VOLUME STATUS: Feature SIADH CSW Volume status Euvolemic Hypovolemic BP/HR Normal ↓BP, ↑HR Physical exam No edema, no dehydration Dry mucosa, poor turgor, flat JVP BUN/Cr Normal or low Elevated (hemoconcentration) Urine output Normal/decreased Increased This patient has CSW: • Decreased BP from baseline • Tachycardia • Dry mucous membranes • Flat neck veins • Elevated BUN (28) with normal creatinine suggests volume depletion Treatment differs completely: CSW (hypovolemic) → Volume replacement with isotonic saline • Replace sodium and water losses • Restores intravascular volume • Correct hyponatremia gradually (<8–10 mEq/L per 24 hours to prevent osmotic demyelination) SIADH (euvolemic) → Fluid restriction • Excess free water is the problem • NS would worsen hyponatremia in SIADH (kidneys excrete sodium, retain water) Why not (A) fluid restriction? • This would be appropriate for SIADH but dangerous in hypovolemic CSW • Would worsen volume depletion and potentially cause hypotension/shock Why not (C) or (E)? • Demeclocycline and vaptans are used for chronic SIADH, not CSW • Vaptans cause aquaresis (free water loss) — harmful in already volume-depleted patient Clinical pearl: Post-neurosurgical hyponatremia requires careful volume assessment. Getting this wrong can be fatal — fluid restriction in CSW worsens dehydration; fluids in SIADH worsen hyponatremia.

stem:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic for routine follow-up. She feels well and has no specific complaints. She has a history of hypertension 
controlled with lisinopril. She denies fatigue, constipation, cold intolerance, or weight changes. 
Physical examination shows blood pressure 128/78 mm Hg, pulse 72/min, and BMI 26 kg/m². Thyroid is normal in size without nodules. Deep tendon 
reflexes are normal. 
Screening laboratory studies show: 
• 
TSH: 8.2 mIU/L (normal 0.5–4.5) 
• 
Free T4: 1.1 ng/dL (normal 0.8–1.8) 
Repeat testing 6 weeks later confirms: 
• 
TSH: 7.8 mIU/L 
• 
Free T4: 1.0 ng/dL 
• 
Anti-TPO antibodies: positive

Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

options.text: Observation with repeat TSH in 6–12 months
options.label: B

explanation: This patient has subclinical hypothyroidism: elevated TSH with normal free T4. The decision to treat depends on several factors: Indications to TREAT subclinical hypothyroidism: 1. TSH >10 mIU/L — treat regardless of symptoms 2. TSH 5–10 mIU/L with: • Symptoms of hypothyroidism • Positive TPO antibodies (predicts progression to overt hypothyroidism) • Goiter • Pregnancy or planning pregnancy • Dyslipidemia • Significant cardiovascular disease • Age <65–70 years This patient should be treated because: • Persistent elevation (confirmed on repeat testing) • TSH 7.8 mIU/L (approaching 10) • Positive anti-TPO antibodies — key factor; indicates autoimmune thyroiditis with ~4.3% annual progression rate to overt hypothyroidism • Age 58 (younger patients benefit more from treatment) • Cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension) Treatment: Low-dose levothyroxine (25–50 µg daily), titrate to normalize TSH Why not (B) observation alone? • Would be appropriate if: • TSH only mildly elevated (5–7) AND • No TPO antibodies AND • No symptoms or risk factors • Positive antibodies change the calculation — progression likely Why not (C) or (D)? • RAI uptake scan is for hyperthyroidism workup • Ultrasound indicated if nodule suspected; not needed for straightforward subclinical hypothyroidism Why not (E)? • T3 monotherapy is not standard treatment for hypothyroidism • Levothyroxine (T4) is the standard of care In elderly patients (>70–80 years): More conservative approach; TSH targets may be higher, as overtreatment risks atrial fibrillation and bone loss.

stem:
A 62-year-old man presents to a rural emergency department with 45 minutes of severe substernal chest pressure radiating to his left arm, associated 
with diaphoresis and nausea. He has a history of hypertension and smoking. 
On examination, he appears anxious and diaphoretic. Blood pressure is 148/92 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, respirations are 20/min. Lungs are clear, and 
there is no jugular venous distension. 
ECG shows 4-mm ST-segment elevation in leads V1–V4 with reciprocal ST depression in leads II, III, and aVF. 
The nearest PCI-capable facility is 95 minutes away by ambulance. The current facility does not have cardiac catheterization capabilities.

Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management?

options.text: Administer aspirin and heparin only, then transfer
options.label: C

options.text: Obtain serial troponins before deciding on treatment
options.label: D

explanation: This patient has an anterior STEMI (ST elevation V1–V4 with reciprocal changes). Immediate reperfusion is critical — "time is myocardium." Decision framework for reperfusion strategy: Primary PCI is preferred if: • Door-to-balloon time <90 minutes at PCI-capable hospital • Door-to-balloon time <120 minutes if transfer required (including transfer time) Fibrinolysis is indicated when: • PCI not available within 120 minutes of first medical contact • No contraindications to fibrinolytics • Symptom onset <12 hours (ideally <3 hours for maximum benefit) This case: • Transfer time alone is 95 minutes • Add door-to-door time, door-to-balloon time at receiving facility → likely >120 minutes total • Patient has clear STEMI with symptoms for only 45 minutes • No stated contraindications to fibrinolytics Fibrinolysis should be administered within 30 minutes of arrival ("door-to-needle") Adjunctive therapy with either strategy: • Aspirin 325 mg (chewed) • P2Y12 inhibitor (clopidogrel if fibrinolysis; ticagrelor/prasugrel if PCI) • Anticoagulation (heparin) • Consider transfer for rescue PCI after fibrinolysis Why not (B)? • Would exceed the 120-minute window • Delays reperfusion → larger infarct → higher mortality Why not (C)? • Incomplete therapy — aspirin and heparin alone don't provide reperfusion Why not (D) or (E)? • STEMI is a clinical and ECG diagnosis • Troponins take time and should not delay reperfusion • Stress testing is contraindicated in acute MI Key time targets: • Door-to-needle: ≤30 minutes • Door-to-balloon: ≤90 minutes (same hospital) or ≤120 minutes (transfer)

stem:
A 64-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy returns for follow-up. His last echocardiogram showed left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%. He 
reports New York Heart Association class II symptoms — dyspnea with moderate exertion but comfortable at rest. 
Current medications: 
• 
Lisinopril 20 mg daily 
• 
Carvedilol 25 mg twice daily 
• 
Furosemide 40 mg daily 
• 
Atorvastatin 40 mg daily 
Vital signs: blood pressure 118/72 mm Hg, pulse 64/min. Physical examination shows no peripheral edema, jugular venous pressure is normal, and lungs 
are clear. 
Laboratory studies: 

• 
Serum potassium: 4.2 mEq/L 
• 
Serum creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL 
• 
eGFR: 72 mL/min/1.73m²

Which of the following additional medications would provide a mortality benefit?
explanation: This patient has HFrEF (EF ≤40%) on suboptimal GDMT. The "four pillars" of mortality-reducing therapy in HFrEF are: Drug Class Example Mortality Benefit ACE-I/ARB/ARNI Lisinopril, Sacubitril-valsartan ✓ Yes Beta-blocker Carvedilol, Metoprolol succinate, Bisoprolol ✓ Yes MRA Spironolactone, Eplerenone ✓ Yes SGLT2 inhibitor Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin ✓ Yes This patient is missing an MRA (mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist) Evidence for spironolactone (RALES trial): • 30% reduction in mortality in NYHA III–IV HF • Also reduces hospitalizations • Indicated for EF ≤35% (some extend to ≤40%) with NYHA II–IV symptoms Before starting, verify: • K+ <5.0 mEq/L ✓ (this patient: 4.2) • eGFR >30 mL/min ✓ (this patient: 72) • No history of hyperkalemia Why not other options? (A) Digoxin: • Reduces HF hospitalizations • Does NOT reduce mortality • Used for symptom control or rate control in atrial fibrillation (B) Hydralazine and (E) Isosorbide dinitrate: • Combination (Hydralazine-ISDN) provides mortality benefit specifically in African American patients with HFrEF • Not first-line for all patients; added if ACE-I/ARB not tolerated or in addition to GDMT in African Americans (D) Amlodipine: • Safe in HF (unlike other calcium channel blockers) • Does NOT reduce mortality • Used only if additional BP or angina control needed Next optimization steps for this patient: 1. Add spironolactone 12.5–25 mg daily 2. Consider switching ACE-I to ARNI (sacubitril-valsartan) — superior mortality benefit 3. Add SGLT2 inhibitor 4. Assess for ICD indication (EF ≤35% on GDMT for ≥3 months)

stem:
A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset dyspnea and right-sided pleuritic chest pain that began 6 hours ago. 
She returned from a 14-hour international flight 3 days ago. She has no significant medical history and takes oral contraceptives. 
On examination, she is alert and anxious. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, respirations are 22/min, and 
oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Lungs are clear, and there is no lower extremity edema or calf tenderness. 
CT pulmonary angiography shows a segmental pulmonary embolus in the right lower lobe. Echocardiogram shows normal right ventricular size and 
function. Troponin I is 0.02 ng/mL (normal <0.04). BNP is 45 pg/mL (normal <100).

Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

options.text: Admit to telemetry for IV heparin and monitoring
options.label: B

options.text: Discharge with rivaroxaban and outpatient follow-up
options.label: C

options.text: Admit for observation and IVC filter placement
options.label: D

explanation: This patient has an acute pulmonary embolism with features suggesting low risk for adverse outcomes: Risk stratification for PE: High-risk (massive) PE: • Hemodynamic instability (SBP <90, shock) • Requires ICU, consider thrombolysis Intermediate-risk (submassive) PE: • Hemodynamically stable BUT • RV dysfunction on echo OR elevated troponin/BNP • Requires admission for monitoring Low-risk PE: • Hemodynamically stable AND • No RV dysfunction AND • Normal biomarkers AND • Low clinical risk score (sPESI = 0 or PESI class I–II) This patient is LOW RISK: • Hemodynamically stable ✓ • Normal RV function on echo ✓ • Normal troponin ✓ • Normal BNP ✓ • Simplified PESI (sPESI) score: likely 0 (no hypotension, no hypoxia <90%, no cancer, no chronic cardiopulmonary disease, no altered mental status, age <80) Low-risk PE can be managed as outpatient with: • Direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC): rivaroxaban, apixaban, or edoxaban • Duration: Provoked PE (flight + OCPs) → 3 months minimum • Close follow-up within 1 week Why not (A)? • Thrombolysis reserved for massive PE with hemodynamic instability • This patient is stable with no RV strain Why not (B)? • Unnecessary hospitalization for low-risk PE • Increases costs, VTE risk from immobility, nosocomial risks Why not (D)? • IVC filter only if anticoagulation contraindicated • This patient can be anticoagulated Why not (E)? • Aspirin is not treatment for PE • Requires anticoagulation DOAC advantages: No bridging required, fixed dosing, no INR monitoring (for rivaroxaban/apixaban)

stem:
A 68-year-old man with COPD (FEV1 45% predicted) presents with 3 days of worsening dyspnea, increased sputum production, and change in sputum 
from white to yellow-green. He uses tiotropium and albuterol inhalers at home. He has had two COPD exacerbations requiring hospitalization in the past 
year. 
On examination, temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg, pulse is 94/min, respirations are 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 89% 
on room air. He has diffuse expiratory wheezes and is using accessory muscles. There are no signs of consolidation. 
Chest X-ray shows hyperinflation without infiltrate.

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment regimen?

options.text: Oral prednisone plus azithromycin plus increased bronchodilators
options.label: C

options.text: Intravenous antibiotics plus bronchodilators without steroids
options.label: D

explanation: This patient has an acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD) meeting criteria for antibiotic therapy. Anthonisen criteria for AECOPD severity: 1. Increased dyspnea 2. Increased sputum volume 3. Increased sputum purulence (change in color) Antibiotic indications: • All 3 cardinal symptoms present (Type 1 — severe) → Antibiotics indicated • 2 of 3 symptoms IF one is purulence → Antibiotics indicated • Mechanical ventilation required → Antibiotics indicated • Mild exacerbation (1 symptom) → No antibiotics This patient has ALL 3: • ✓ Increased dyspnea • ✓ Increased sputum volume • ✓ Purulent sputum (yellow-green) Standard AECOPD treatment: Component Details Bronchodilators SABA (albuterol) ± SAMA (ipratropium), nebulized if severe Systemic corticosteroids Prednisone 40 mg × 5 days Antibiotics (if indicated) Azithromycin, doxycycline, or respiratory fluoroquinolone Oxygen Target SpO2 88–92% Why not (A)? • Missing corticosteroids and antibiotics; inadequate for this severity Why not (B)? • Missing antibiotics despite meeting criteria (Type 1 exacerbation) Why not (D)? • IV antibiotics not necessary for uncomplicated AECOPD without pneumonia • Missing systemic steroids (proven to reduce treatment failure and hospital stay) Why not (E)? • Inhaled steroids have no role in acute exacerbation management • Systemic steroids required Antibiotic choice: Cover typical pathogens (H. influenzae, M. catarrhalis, S. pneumoniae) • Azithromycin or doxycycline for most • Fluoroquinolone if recent antibiotic use or Pseudomonas risk

stem:
A 72-year-old man presents with 4 days of productive cough with rust-colored sputum, fever, and pleuritic chest pain. He has well-controlled 
hypertension and type 2 diabetes. 
On examination, temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 102/64 mm Hg, pulse is 108/min, respirations are 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 
91% on room air. He is oriented to person, place, and time. Right lower lung field has bronchial breath sounds and dullness to percussion. 
Laboratory studies show BUN 24 mg/dL (normal 7–20) and WBC 18,400/µL. 
Chest X-ray shows right lower lobe consolidation.

Which of the following is the most appropriate disposition?

options.text: Discharge with oral azithromycin plus amoxicillin
options.label: B

options.text: Admit to medical ward for IV antibiotics
options.label: C

options.text: Admit to ICU for IV antibiotics and monitoring
options.label: D

options.text: Observe in ED for 6 hours, then discharge
options.label: E

explanation: This patient has community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) requiring severity assessment for disposition. CURB-65 score (1 point each): • Confusion → No (0) • Uremia (BUN >19 mg/dL or >7 mmol/L) → Yes (1) • Respiratory rate ≥30 → No, but close at 26 (0) • Blood pressure (SBP <90 or DBP ≤60) → DBP 64, borderline (0 or 1) • Age ≥65 → Yes (1) Score: 2–3 points CURB-65 interpretation: Score Mortality Risk Disposition 0–1 Low (1.5%) Outpatient 2 Intermediate (9.2%) Consider admission 3–5 High (22%) Admit; ≥4 consider ICU Additional concerning features: • Hypoxemia (SpO2 91%) • Elderly with comorbidities (DM) • Borderline hypotension • Elevated WBC suggesting significant infection This patient warrants hospital admission but does not meet ICU criteria. ICU admission criteria (any one major or ≥3 minor): • Major: Septic shock requiring vasopressors, mechanical ventilation • Minor: RR ≥30, PaO2/FiO2 ≤250, multilobar infiltrates, confusion, BUN ≥20, WBC <4000, platelets <100,000, hypothermia, hypotension requiring fluids Inpatient treatment (non-ICU): • Respiratory fluoroquinolone (levofloxacin or moxifloxacin) alone, OR • Beta-lactam (ceftriaxone, ampicillin-sulbactam) PLUS macrolide (azithromycin) Why not (A) or (B)? • Outpatient therapy inappropriate given severity score and hypoxemia Why not (D)? • Does not meet major ICU criteria (hemodynamically stable, not in respiratory failure) Why not (E)? • Brief observation insufficient; requires admission

stem:
A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department after vomiting approximately 500 mL of bright red blood 2 hours ago. He has a history of 
alcohol use disorder and takes ibuprofen regularly for back pain. He denies abdominal pain. 
On examination, he is anxious but alert. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 98/62 mm Hg (108/70 after 1L NS), pulse is 112/min (98 after 
fluids), respirations are 18/min. Abdomen is soft, nontender. Rectal examination shows melena. 
Laboratory studies: 
• 
Hemoglobin: 8.4 g/dL (baseline 14 g/dL) 
• 
Platelets: 142,000/µL 
• 
INR: 1.2 
• 
BUN: 42 mg/dL 
• 
Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL

After initial resuscitation and IV PPI, which of the following is the most appropriate timing for esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD)?
explanation: This patient has acute upper GI bleeding (hematemesis with melena) requiring risk stratification for EGD timing. Risk assessment (Glasgow-Blatchford Score — GBS): • BUN 42 → 4 points • Hemoglobin 8.4 (male) → 3 points • SBP 98 → 2 points • Pulse ≥100 → 1 point • Melena → 1 point • Total: ~11 points → High risk EGD timing guidelines: Clinical Scenario Timing Hemodynamic instability unresponsive to resuscitation, ongoing hemorrhage Emergent (within 12 hours, some say <6 hours) High-risk but hemodynamically stabilized Urgent (within 24 hours) ← This patient Low-risk (GBS 0–1) May be appropriate for outpatient This patient: • High-risk features (significant hemoglobin drop, melena, elevated BUN) • BUT responded to fluid resuscitation (BP and HR improved) • Appropriate for EGD within 24 hours (not emergency <12 hours) Why within 24 hours, not immediately? • Studies show no mortality benefit of <6 hour EGD vs <24 hour EGD in hemodynamically stable patients • Allows adequate resuscitation, correction of coagulopathy if needed • Improved visualization with controlled endoscopy Immediate/emergent EGD (<12 hours) indicated if: • Ongoing hemodynamic instability despite resuscitation • Signs of continued active bleeding • High suspicion for variceal bleed with instability Pre-endoscopy management: • IV PPI (pantoprazole 80 mg bolus then infusion) • Transfuse if Hgb <7 g/dL (or <8–9 in CAD) • Correct coagulopathy (INR 1.2 is acceptable) • NPO, prokinetic (erythromycin) may improve visualization Why not (A)? • Patient stabilized; no evidence emergent EGD improves outcomes in this scenario Why not (D) or (E)? • Delayed endoscopy increases risk of rebleeding and missed high-risk lesions

stem:
A 56-year-old man with alcoholic cirrhosis and ascites presents with 2 days of worsening abdominal pain, fever, and confusion. He had a prior episode of 
spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) 8 months ago but stopped taking prophylactic antibiotics. 
On examination, temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min. He is disoriented. Abdomen is distended with diffuse 
tenderness and positive fluid wave. There is no rebound tenderness. 
Diagnostic paracentesis is performed: 

• 
Ascitic fluid WBC: 680 cells/µL 
• 
Ascitic fluid PMN (neutrophils): 420 cells/µL 
• 
Ascitic fluid protein: 0.8 g/dL 
• 
Ascitic fluid culture: pending 
• 
Ascitic fluid glucose: 85 mg/dL 
• 
Serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG): 1.8 g/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.text: Await culture results before starting antibiotics
options.label: A

options.text: Start IV cefotaxime and albumin infusion
options.label: B

explanation: This patient has spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), diagnosed clinically and confirmed by paracentesis. Diagnostic criteria for SBP: • Ascitic fluid PMN count ≥250 cells/µL ← This patient has 420 • Culture may be negative in up to 40% ("culture-negative neutrocytic ascites") DO NOT wait for culture results — SBP is a clinical diagnosis requiring immediate treatment Treatment of SBP: Component Details Antibiotics IV 3rd-generation cephalosporin (cefotaxime 2g q8h) × 5 days Albumin 1.5 g/kg on day 1, 1 g/kg on day 3 Alternative antibiotics Ceftriaxone, fluoroquinolone (if no recent FQ use) Why albumin? • Reduces mortality and hepatorenal syndrome risk • Study showed mortality reduction from 29% to 10% when albumin added to antibiotics • Indicated especially if: Cr >1 mg/dL, BUN >30 mg/dL, or bilirubin >4 mg/dL This patient should receive albumin because: • Hypotension (SBP 94) • Altered mental status (hepatic encephalopathy or sepsis) • Prior SBP episode (high-risk) Why not (A)? • Cultures take 24–48+ hours; SBP mortality increases with treatment delay • PMN ≥250 is sufficient to diagnose and treat Why not (C)? • Oral fluoroquinolone inadequate for active SBP with sepsis • Reserved for prophylaxis, not treatment • Additionally, this patient was on FQ prophylaxis → may have resistant organisms Why not (D)? • SBP is treated medically, not surgically • Secondary bacterial peritonitis (from perforation) would show: glucose <50, LDH elevation, protein >1 g/dL, multiple organisms, polymicrobial Why not (E)? • Treatment should start immediately • Repeat paracentesis at 48 hours is done to confirm response (>25% decrease in PMN) Secondary prophylaxis: After recovery, lifelong norfloxacin or TMP-SMX (this patient needs to restart)

stem:
A 44-year-old woman presents with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back for 12 hours, associated with nausea and vomiting. She drinks 4–5 
glasses of wine daily. She has had similar but milder episodes before. 
On examination, temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), blood pressure is 104/68 mm Hg, pulse is 108/min. She has epigastric tenderness with guarding but no 
rebound. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. 
Laboratory studies: 
• 
Lipase: 1,842 U/L (normal <160) 
• 
WBC: 16,200/µL 
• 
Hematocrit: 48% 
• 
BUN: 32 mg/dL 
• 
Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL 
• 
Glucose: 186 mg/dL 
• 
AST: 58 U/L 
• 
Calcium: 7.8 mg/dL 
• 
LDH: 420 U/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

options.text: IV antibiotics to prevent infected necrosis
options.label: C

explanation: This patient has acute pancreatitis (epigastric pain + lipase >3× upper limit of normal). Severity assessment using Ranson criteria at admission: • Age >55 → No (44) • WBC >16,000 → Yes ✓ • Glucose >200 → No (186) • AST >250 → No • LDH >350 → Yes ✓ Additional concerning features: • Elevated BUN (32) → predictor of severity • Elevated hematocrit (48%) → hemoconcentration indicating third-spacing • Hypocalcemia (7.8) → marker of severe pancreatitis • Tachycardia with borderline hypotension → early hypovolemia This is likely moderately severe to severe pancreatitis requiring aggressive management. Initial management priorities: 1. Aggressive IV fluid resuscitation — MOST IMPORTANT • Goal-directed: 250–500 mL/hr of LR (preferred) or NS • Target: urine output >0.5 mL/kg/hr, decreasing BUN, normalizing vitals • First 12–24 hours are critical; fluid needs are highest early • Prevents pancreatic necrosis by maintaining perfusion 2. Pain control (IV opioids) 3. NPO initially (consider early enteral feeding if tolerated) 4. Monitor for organ failure (respiratory, renal, cardiovascular) Why not (A)? • CT is not indicated initially unless: • Diagnosis uncertain • No improvement after 48–72 hours (concern for necrosis/complications) • Early CT can underestimate necrosis; inflammation takes time to develop Why not (C)? • Prophylactic antibiotics do NOT prevent infected necrosis • Antibiotics only indicated for documented infection (infected necrosis, cholangitis) Why not (D)? • ERCP indicated for gallstone pancreatitis with concurrent cholangitis or persistent biliary obstruction • This appears to be alcohol-related; no indication for ERCP Why not (E)? • TPN avoided; enteral nutrition preferred (maintains gut barrier) • Early oral/enteral feeding (within 24–48 hours) if tolerated improves outcomes

stem:
A 78-year-old woman is admitted with community-acquired pneumonia. She has hypertension treated with lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Due to 
poor oral intake and fever, she has been volume depleted. On hospital day 2, you note her creatinine has risen from 1.1 mg/dL on admission to 2.4 
mg/dL. 
Physical examination shows blood pressure 102/68 mm Hg (baseline 138/82), pulse 96/min, dry mucous membranes, and decreased skin turgor. Urine 
output has been 15 mL/hr over the past 6 hours. 
Urine studies: 
• 
Urine sodium: 8 mEq/L 
• 
Urine creatinine: 112 mg/dL 
• 
Serum creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL 
• 
Fractional excretion of sodium (FENa): 0.3% 
• 
Urine osmolality: 650 mOsm/kg 
• 
Urine microscopy: Few hyaline casts, no cells or cellular casts

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: This patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) in the setting of volume depletion. The urine studies help differentiate prerenal from intrinsic causes. Urine indices comparison: Parameter Prerenal ATN (Intrinsic) Urine sodium <20 mEq/L >40 mEq/L FENa <1% >2% Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg <350 mOsm/kg BUN:Cr ratio >20:1 <15:1 Urine sediment Bland, hyaline casts Muddy brown granular casts This patient's findings: • Urine sodium 8 mEq/L → Low (<20) ✓ • FENa 0.3% → <1% ✓ • Urine osmolality 650 → Concentrated (>500) ✓ • Bland sediment with hyaline casts ✓ All consistent with PRERENAL AZOTEMIA Pathophysiology: The kidneys are appropriately retaining sodium and water in response to decreased perfusion. Tubular function is intact. Clinical context supports prerenal: • Volume depletion (poor intake, fever, dry mucosa) • Hypotension below baseline • On diuretics and ACE inhibitor (reduced GFR autoregulation) Management: • IV fluid resuscitation • Hold diuretics and ACE inhibitor temporarily • Expect creatinine to improve within 24–48 hours Why not (A) ATN? • FENa would be >2% • Urine would be dilute (osmolality <350) • Would see muddy brown granular casts Why not (B) AIN? • Usually drug-induced (NSAIDs, antibiotics, PPIs) • Would see WBC casts, eosinophiluria • Often presents with fever, rash, eosinophilia (but not always) Why not (D)? • Postrenal requires obstruction (bilateral or single functioning kidney) • No symptoms suggesting obstruction, no hydronephrosis mentioned Why not (E)? • No contrast exposure mentioned Caveat: FENa can be <1% in ATN if caused by contrast, myoglobin, or early sepsis. Use FEUrea (<35% prerenal) if on diuretics.

stem:
A 62-year-old man with end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis missed his last two sessions due to transportation issues. He presents with generalized 
weakness and palpitations. 
On examination, blood pressure is 168/98 mm Hg, pulse is 52/min and irregular. He has 2+ lower extremity edema bilaterally. 
ECG shows peaked T waves, prolonged PR interval, and widening of the QRS complex. 
Laboratory studies: 
• 
Serum potassium: 7.8 mEq/L 
• 
Serum bicarbonate: 16 mEq/L 
• 
Serum creatinine: 8.9 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate FIRST step in management?
explanation: This patient has severe hyperkalemia (K+ 7.8) with ECG changes — a life-threatening emergency. The ECG progression of hyperkalemia: 1. Peaked T waves (early) 2. Prolonged PR interval 3. Widened QRS 4. Sine wave pattern 5. VFib/asystole This patient has advanced ECG changes (peaked T, prolonged PR, wide QRS) → imminent risk of fatal arrhythmia Treatment sequence for severe hyperkalemia: Step Treatment Mechanism Onset 1. FIRST IV Calcium gluconate Stabilizes cardiac membrane 1–3 min 2. Insulin + glucose Shifts K+ into cells 15–30 min 3. Sodium bicarbonate Shifts K+ into cells (if acidotic) 30–60 min 3. Beta-agonist (albuterol) Shifts K+ into cells 15–30 min 4. Definitive removal Dialysis, Kayexalate, patiromer Hours Why calcium FIRST? • Does NOT lower potassium • Directly antagonizes the cardiac membrane effects of hyperkalemia • Provides immediate protection against arrhythmia • Buys time for other treatments to work Why not (A) insulin/glucose first? • Insulin lowers potassium but takes 15–30 minutes • With ECG changes, patient may develop fatal arrhythmia before insulin works • Calcium stabilizes the heart within minutes Why not (C) Kayexalate? • Removes potassium from body but takes hours to work • Not appropriate for acute emergency • Role is in removal after stabilization Why not (D) dialysis first? • Definitive treatment but takes time to arrange • Patient may arrest while waiting • Start dialysis after initial stabilization Why not (E) bicarbonate first? • Less effective than insulin for potassium shift • Useful adjunct if metabolic acidosis present • Not first-line Complete management sequence for this patient: 1. IV calcium gluconate 1–2 g → monitor ECG for narrowing QRS 2. Insulin 10 units IV + D50 25 g (or D10 drip) 3. Emergent hemodialysis

stem:
A 58-year-old woman with acute myeloid leukemia completed her third cycle of chemotherapy 10 days ago. She presents with fever (38.9°C/102°F) and 
mild fatigue. She denies cough, diarrhea, urinary symptoms, or skin changes. She has a tunneled central venous catheter in place. 
On examination, she appears tired but comfortable. Blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min. Examination of the catheter site shows no 
erythema or discharge. Lungs are clear. Abdomen is soft, nontender. 
Laboratory studies: 
• 
WBC: 400/µL with ANC 80/µL 
• 
Hemoglobin: 9.2 g/dL 
• 
Platelets: 34,000/µL 
Chest X-ray shows no infiltrates.

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antibiotic therapy?

options.text: Wait for blood culture results before starting antibiotics
options.label: E

explanation: This patient has febrile neutropenia — a medical emergency: • Fever: Single temperature ≥38.3°C (101°F) OR ≥38.0°C (100.4°F) sustained for ≥1 hour • Neutropenia: ANC <500/µL OR ANC <1000/µL expected to decline to <500 • This patient: ANC 80/µL with fever 38.9°C Key principle: Start empiric antibiotics IMMEDIATELY. Do not wait for culture results or localizing signs. Initial empiric therapy options (IDSA guidelines): Regimen Examples Anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam monotherapy Cefepime, piperacillin-tazobactam, meropenem, imipenem Dual therapy (if indicated) Add vancomycin or aminoglycoside for specific indications Cefepime is appropriate because: • Broad-spectrum anti-pseudomonal coverage • Covers most gram-negative pathogens (including Pseudomonas) • Adequate gram-positive coverage for initial empiric therapy • Monotherapy is standard initial approach When to ADD vancomycin to initial regimen: • Hemodynamic instability/sepsis • Skin/soft tissue infection • Catheter-related infection suspected (erythema, tunnel tenderness) • Known MRSA colonization • Gram-positive cocci on blood culture • Severe mucositis • Pneumonia • Fluoroquinolone prophylaxis (increased risk of gram-positive infection) This patient has NONE of these indications — stable vital signs, no catheter site infection, no mucositis, no pneumonia → vancomycin not needed initially. Why not (A)? • Vancomycin alone has no gram-negative coverage — unacceptable Why not (C)? • Ceftriaxone lacks anti-pseudomonal activity • Metronidazole adds anaerobic coverage but not gram-negative/Pseudomonas Why not (D)? • Oral fluoroquinolone regimen may be appropriate for low-risk outpatients • This patient has AML, profound neutropenia (ANC 80), central catheter → HIGH RISK • Requires IV therapy and admission Why not (E)? • NEVER delay antibiotics in febrile neutropenia • Mortality increases with each hour of delayed antibiotic therapy

stem:
A 34-year-old man who uses IV heroin presents with 2 weeks of fever, night sweats, and malaise. He also reports progressive dyspnea and a new cough 
productive of blood-tinged sputum. 
On examination, temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), blood pressure is 108/62 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min. There is a 3/6 holosystolic 
murmur at the left lower sternal border that increases with inspiration. Examination reveals splinter hemorrhages and tender nodules on the fingertips. 
Lungs have scattered crackles bilaterally. 
Laboratory studies show WBC 18,400/µL and hemoglobin 10.2 g/dL. Chest X-ray shows multiple bilateral peripheral nodular infiltrates, some with 
cavitation. 
Blood cultures are drawn and sent.

Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic regimen while awaiting culture results?
explanation: This patient has clinical features consistent with infective endocarditis (IE) with likely tricuspid valve involvement (right-sided IE). Modified Duke Criteria assessment: Major criteria: 1. Blood cultures pending (likely to be positive if IE) 2. Echocardiographic evidence of vegetation (not yet done, but murmur + IVDU highly suggestive) Minor criteria: 1. ✓ Predisposing condition (IVDU) 2. ✓ Fever 3. ✓ Vascular phenomena: septic pulmonary emboli (cavitary lung nodules + hemoptysis) 4. ✓ Immunologic phenomena: Osler nodes (tender fingertip nodules) Clinical picture: • IVDU → Right-sided (tricuspid) IE most common • Tricuspid regurgitation murmur (holosystolic at LLSB, increases with inspiration) • Septic pulmonary emboli → multiple cavitary lung nodules • Most likely organism: Staphylococcus aureus (especially MRSA in IVDU) Empiric treatment for native valve IE in IVDU: Context Empiric Regimen IVDU, native valve Vancomycin (MRSA coverage) + gentamicin Non-IVDU, native valve Ceftriaxone + vancomycin (or nafcillin if low MRSA risk) Prosthetic valve Vancomycin + gentamicin + rifampin Why vancomycin + gentamicin? • Vancomycin: MRSA coverage essential in IVDU population (high prevalence) • Gentamicin: Synergistic killing, enhances bactericidal activity against staphylococci • Adjust/narrow once cultures speciate Why not (B)? • Ceftriaxone lacks MRSA coverage • Would be appropriate for streptococcal IE but not empiric for IVDU Why not (C)? • Penicillin G for penicillin-susceptible streptococci only • Inadequate for empiric therapy Why not (D)? • Vancomycin monotherapy adequate for some cases but gentamicin adds synergy for serious S. aureus infection Why not (E)? • Not a standard IE regimen • Rifampin is added for prosthetic valve IE, not native valve Next steps: Obtain echocardiogram (TTE first, may need TEE), follow blood cultures, narrow antibiotics when sensitivities available

stem:
A 64-year-old woman is postoperative day 7 after hip replacement surgery. She has been receiving subcutaneous unfractionated heparin for DVT 
prophylaxis since admission. The nurse reports that her platelet count has decreased significantly. 
Review of laboratory values: 
• 
Preoperative platelets: 248,000/µL 
• 
POD 2: 234,000/µL 
• 
POD 5: 168,000/µL 
• 
POD 7 (today): 89,000/µL 
She has no bleeding symptoms but reports new pain and swelling in her left calf. On examination, the left calf is 3 cm larger in circumference than the 
right with tenderness and warmth.

Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management?

options.text: Discontinue heparin and observe platelet count
options.label: D

explanation: This patient has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), a prothrombotic disorder paradoxically caused by heparin. 4Ts Score for HIT: Criterion This Patient Points Thrombocytopenia (50% fall or nadir 20–100K) 89K (64% fall from baseline) 2 Timing (5–10 days after heparin start) Day 7 of heparin 2 Thrombosis or other sequelae New DVT suspected (calf swelling) 2 OTher causes for thrombocytopenia None apparent (postop, no sepsis) 2 Score: 8 (High probability) Key features of HIT: • Onset 5–10 days after heparin exposure (or sooner if prior exposure) • Platelet drop >50% from baseline (or to <150,000) • Paradoxical thrombosis (arterial or venous) — NOT bleeding • Antibodies against platelet factor 4-heparin complex Management principles: 1. STOP ALL HEPARIN — including heparin flushes, LMWH, heparin-coated catheters 2. Start non-heparin anticoagulant immediately — patients are hypercoagulable • Argatroban (direct thrombin inhibitor) — preferred in renal impairment • Bivalirudin — for PCI • Fondaparinux — sometimes used but technically a heparinoid 3. Do NOT give warfarin until platelets recover — warfarin causes protein C drop, increasing thrombosis risk 4. Do NOT transfuse platelets — "fuel for the fire"; increases thrombosis risk 5. Send HIT antibody testing (PF4/heparin ELISA, serotonin release assay) Why not (A)? • Continuing heparin worsens HIT; platelets may trigger more thrombosis Why not (B)? • Warfarin alone is contraindicated in acute HIT • Must wait until platelets >150,000 AND on therapeutic non-heparin anticoagulant • Warfarin monotherapy causes warfarin-induced skin necrosis/limb gangrene Why not (D)? • Observation inadequate — 50% of HIT patients develop thrombosis if untreated Why not (E)? • LMWH cross-reacts with HIT antibodies in ~90% of cases • Contraindicated in HIT

stem:
A 22-year-old man is newly diagnosed with Burkitt lymphoma with extensive abdominal lymphadenopathy. CT shows multiple bulky retroperitoneal 
lymph nodes with the largest measuring 12 cm. Laboratory studies show WBC 32,000/µL, LDH 2,450 U/L (normal <250), uric acid 9.8 mg/dL, potassium 
4.6 mEq/L, phosphorus 5.2 mg/dL, and creatinine 1.2 mg/dL. 
Chemotherapy is planned to begin tomorrow.

Which of the following is the most appropriate prophylactic management?

options.text: Rasburicase, aggressive IV hydration, and close monitoring
options.label: A

options.text: Observation with treatment if TLS develops
options.label: D

options.text: Delay chemotherapy until uric acid normalizes
options.label: E

explanation: This patient is at HIGH RISK for tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) and requires aggressive prophylaxis. TLS risk factors present: • Burkitt lymphoma (one of highest TLS risk malignancies) • Bulky disease (12 cm lymph node mass) • Elevated LDH (marker of tumor burden/cell turnover) • Elevated baseline uric acid (9.8 mg/dL) • High WBC TLS involves release of intracellular contents causing: • ↑ Potassium → arrhythmias • ↑ Phosphorus → binds calcium → hypocalcemia → tetany, arrhythmias • ↑ Uric acid → crystallizes in renal tubules → AKI • ↑ LDH (marker) Risk stratification and prophylaxis: Risk Level Examples Prophylaxis High Burkitt, lymphoblastic lymphoma, AML with WBC >100K, bulky disease, elevated LDH/uric acid Rasburicase + aggressive hydration Intermediate Most hematologic malignancies Allopurinol + hydration Low Solid tumors, indolent lymphomas Hydration ± allopurinol Why rasburicase for high-risk? • Recombinant urate oxidase • Rapidly converts uric acid to allantoin (soluble, easily excreted) • Works within hours (vs. days for allopurinol) • Prevents uric acid nephropathy • Critical when uric acid already elevated or very high tumor burden Why not (B) allopurinol alone? • Allopurinol only prevents NEW uric acid formation (blocks xanthine oxidase) • Does not break down existing uric acid • Takes days to lower uric acid • Inadequate for high-risk patients with elevated baseline uric acid Why not (C)? • Urine alkalinization was historically used but now discouraged • Increases calcium phosphate precipitation (more dangerous than uric acid crystals) • Not recommended by current guidelines Why not (D)? • Treating TLS after it develops is much harder than preventing it • Dialysis often required; significant mortality Why not (E)? • Delaying chemotherapy for aggressive lymphoma worsens outcomes • Rasburicase allows safe initiation of chemotherapy Additional measures: • IV hydration 2–3 L/m²/day • Monitor electrolytes q6–8 hours • Avoid potassium in IV fluids • Dialysis if AKI or refractory hyperkalemia/hyperphosphatemia Rasburicase contraindication: G6PD deficiency (causes hemolysis)

stem:
A 24-year-old man with sickle cell disease presents with fever, cough, and chest pain for 2 days. He was admitted 4 days ago for a vaso-occlusive pain 
crisis affecting his lower back and legs and has been receiving IV morphine and fluids. 
On examination, temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), blood pressure is 102/68 mm Hg, pulse is 118/min, respirations are 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 
88% on room air. He appears in moderate distress. Lung examination reveals decreased breath sounds and crackles at the left base. He has mild scleral 
icterus. 
Laboratory studies: 
• 
Hemoglobin: 6.8 g/dL (baseline 8.5 g/dL) 
• 
WBC: 18,200/µL 
• 
Reticulocyte count: 1.2% (low for hemolysis) 
• 
LDH: 680 U/L 
Chest X-ray shows a new left lower lobe infiltrate not present on admission.

Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management?

options.text: Simple blood transfusion to hemoglobin 10 g/dL
options.label: A

options.text: Supplemental oxygen and incentive spirometry only
options.label: C

options.text: Increase morphine dose for pain control
options.label: E

explanation: This patient has acute chest syndrome (ACS), the leading cause of death in sickle cell disease. Diagnosis of ACS: • New pulmonary infiltrate on imaging • PLUS at least ONE of: • Fever • Chest pain • Respiratory symptoms (cough, dyspnea) • Hypoxia This patient has ALL features: New infiltrate + fever + chest pain + cough + hypoxia (88%) ACS often develops during hospitalization for pain crisis — this presentation is classic. Severity assessment: Feature Mild/Moderate Severe Oxygen requirement Low-flow High-flow, worsening Respiratory distress Mild Moderate-severe Multilobar involvement No Yes, or rapidly progressing Hemoglobin drop Mild Significant (>2 g/dL) This patient has SEVERE ACS: • Significant hypoxia (88% on room air) • Hemoglobin dropped 1.7 g/dL from baseline • Tachypnea (RR 28), tachycardia • Low reticulocyte count suggests bone marrow suppression (parvovirus? infarction?) Management of severe ACS: Priority Intervention 1 Exchange transfusion (reduces HbS% to <30%) 2 Supplemental oxygen (target SpO2 >95%) 3 Antibiotics (cover atypical + typical pathogens) 4 Bronchodilators if wheezing 5 Incentive spirometry (prevents atelectasis) 6 Pain control (avoid over-sedation) Why exchange transfusion over simple transfusion? • More rapidly decreases HbS percentage • Prevents hyperviscosity (simple transfusion raises hemoglobin but doesn't reduce HbS as effectively) • Indicated for severe ACS, stroke, multiorgan failure When is simple transfusion acceptable? • Mild ACS with modest hemoglobin drop • Target Hgb 10 g/dL (not higher to avoid hyperviscosity) Why not (C)? • Supplemental oxygen and incentive spirometry are supportive but inadequate alone for severe ACS • Needed, but transfusion is the priority Why not (D)? • Bronchoscopy may be considered if unusual pathogen suspected but not first-line • Empiric antibiotics appropriate Why not (E)? • Excessive opioids cause hypoventilation/atelectasis → worsens ACS • Pain control important but should use multimodal approach

stem:
A 72-year-old woman presents with severe new-onset headache for the past 2 weeks, located primarily over her right temple. She also reports jaw pain 
when chewing that resolves with rest, and she noticed blurred vision in her right eye yesterday that resolved after a few minutes. She has had fatigue, 
low-grade fevers, and unintentional 5-kg weight loss over the past 2 months. She also notes shoulder stiffness. 
On examination, temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), and there is tenderness over the right temporal artery, which feels thickened and has diminished 
pulsation. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows pallor of the optic disc. 
Laboratory studies show ESR 98 mm/hr and CRP 68 mg/L.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.text: Schedule temporal artery biopsy before starting treatment
options.label: A

options.text: Order temporal artery ultrasound before treatment
options.label: C

options.text: Start low-dose aspirin and monitor symptoms
options.label: D

options.text: Refer to ophthalmology for evaluation first
options.label: E

explanation: This patient has giant cell arteritis (GCA) with impending vision loss — a medical emergency. Clinical features of GCA: • Age >50 (usually >70) • New headache (temporal) • Scalp/temporal artery tenderness • Jaw claudication (most specific symptom) • Visual symptoms (amaurosis fugax, diplopia) • Constitutional symptoms (fever, weight loss, fatigue) • Associated polymyalgia rheumatica (shoulder/hip stiffness) Laboratory findings: • ESR markedly elevated (>50, often >100) • Elevated CRP • Possible normocytic anemia, thrombocytosis This patient has HIGH-RISK features: • Amaurosis fugax (transient visual loss) — WARNING of impending permanent blindness • Optic disc pallor — suggests early ischemic optic neuropathy CRITICAL PRINCIPLE: START STEROIDS IMMEDIATELY — DO NOT DELAY FOR BIOPSY Why? • Untreated GCA causes permanent bilateral blindness in 15–20% of patients • Once vision is lost, it rarely recovers • Steroids prevent progression to permanent blindness • Temporal artery biopsy remains positive for 1–2 weeks after starting steroids Treatment: Presentation Steroid Regimen GCA without visual symptoms Prednisone 40–60 mg/day GCA with visual symptoms Prednisone 60–80 mg/day OR IV methylprednisolone 1g/day × 3 days This patient should receive high-dose prednisone immediately. Why not (A) or (C)? • Do NOT wait for biopsy or imaging before treatment • Biopsy can be done within 1–2 weeks while on steroids • Every hour of delay increases blindness risk Why not (D)? • Aspirin may reduce ischemic complications but does not treat GCA • Steroids are disease-modifying Why not (E)? • Ophthalmology consultation is appropriate but should not delay steroid initiation • Start steroids, then refer Additional management: • Temporal artery biopsy (still indicated; remains positive 1–2 weeks after steroids) • Consider tocilizumab for steroid-sparing • PCP prophylaxis and bone protection if prolonged steroid course

stem:
A 58-year-old man with a history of gout (last flare 3 years ago) and type 2 diabetes presents with severe pain, swelling, and redness of his right knee for 
2 days. He denies recent trauma. He reports fever and chills since this morning. 
On examination, temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min. The right knee is erythematous, warm, and swollen 
with a moderate effusion. He cannot bear weight and has severe pain with any range of motion. 
Laboratory studies show WBC 16,400/µL, ESR 78 mm/hr, and serum uric acid 8.9 mg/dL.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.text: Start colchicine and NSAIDs for presumed gout flare
options.label: A

options.text: Start empiric IV antibiotics for presumed septic arthritis
options.label: B

options.text: Order MRI of the knee before intervention
options.label: D

options.text: Start allopurinol to lower uric acid
options.label: E

explanation: This patient presents with acute monoarticular arthritis with features suggesting BOTH gout (history, elevated uric acid) AND septic arthritis (fever, diabetes, systemic symptoms). CRITICAL RULE: Any acute monoarticular arthritis with systemic symptoms requires arthrocentesis to rule out septic arthritis. Why arthrocentesis is mandatory: • Septic arthritis and gout can be clinically indistinguishable • Septic arthritis destroys cartilage within 24–48 hours if untreated • Gout history and elevated uric acid do NOT exclude infection • Coexistent gout and septic arthritis can occur • Only synovial fluid analysis can differentiate Synovial fluid analysis: Parameter Septic Arthritis Gout Normal WBC >50,000 (often >100,000) 2,000–50,000 <200 PMN% >90% >50% <25% Crystals None Needle-shaped, negative birefringent None Gram stain May be positive Negative Negative Culture Positive (60–80%) Negative Negative This patient has RED FLAGS for septic arthritis: • Fever (38.6°C) • Systemic symptoms (chills) • Diabetes (immunocompromised) • Unable to bear weight • Leukocytosis with elevated ESR Why not (A)? • Cannot presume gout without ruling out infection • Treating gout alone while missing septic arthritis → joint destruction, sepsis, death Why not (B)? • Do NOT start antibiotics before obtaining synovial fluid (decreases culture yield) • Arthrocentesis first, then antibiotics if septic arthritis suspected Why not (D)? • MRI may show synovitis/effusion but cannot differentiate gout from infection • Joint aspiration is the diagnostic procedure Why not (E)? • Allopurinol should never be started during an acute gout flare (can worsen/prolong attack) • This patient needs diagnosis first Procedure of joint aspiration in suspected septic arthritis: 1. Aspirate joint (even if on anticoagulation — risk of missing septic arthritis > bleeding risk) 2. Send for: cell count, Gram stain, culture, crystal analysis 3. If septic arthritis confirmed: IV antibiotics + orthopedic consultation for possible surgical drainage

stem:
A 24-year-old man presents with 18 hours of abdominal pain that began around his umbilicus and has now localized to his right lower quadrant. He has 
had nausea and two episodes of vomiting. He has no appetite. 
On examination, temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 124/78 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min. Abdomen shows tenderness at McBurney's point with 
voluntary guarding. Rovsing sign is positive. There is no rebound tenderness. 
Laboratory studies show WBC 14,200/µL with 82% neutrophils and CRP 4.8 mg/dL.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.text: Immediate surgical consultation for laparoscopic appendectomy
options.label: B

options.text: IV antibiotics and discharge with outpatient follow-up
options.label: E

explanation: This patient has a high pretest probability of acute appendicitis based on clinical presentation. Classic appendicitis presentation: • Periumbilical pain → migrating to RLQ (visceral → parietal peritoneum) • Anorexia (almost universal) • Nausea/vomiting (usually after pain onset) • Low-grade fever • RLQ tenderness (McBurney's point) • Positive Rovsing sign (RLQ pain with LLQ palpation) • Leukocytosis with left shift Alvarado Score (MANTRELS): • Migration of pain: 1 • Anorexia: 1 • Nausea/vomiting: 1 • Tenderness in RLQ: 2 • Rebound tenderness: 1 • Elevated temperature: 1 • Leukocytosis: 2 • Shift to left: 1 This patient scores 7–8: HIGH probability When is imaging needed? Clinical Scenario Imaging Approach Classic presentation in young/thin male Often proceed directly to surgery Intermediate probability (Alvarado 5–6) CT abdomen/pelvis Women of childbearing age CT (preferred) or ultrasound first Pregnant women Ultrasound first, then MRI if inconclusive Pediatric Ultrasound first This patient (young male, classic presentation, high Alvarado) can proceed to surgery without imaging, though CT is often obtained in practice to exclude other diagnoses and plan surgery. Acceptable approaches: • Option B (direct to surgery) — appropriate given high clinical probability • CT if any diagnostic uncertainty — would show dilated appendix (>6 mm), periappendiceal fat stranding, appendicolith Why not (A) as NEXT step? • CT is reasonable but not strictly required with this classic presentation • In high-probability cases, imaging delays definitive treatment • Many surgeons will operate based on clinical diagnosis alone Why not (C)? • Ultrasound less sensitive in adults (operator-dependent, body habitus) • CT preferred in adult males when imaging needed Why not (D)? • Observation inappropriate with high clinical probability and systemic signs • Risk of perforation increases with delay Why not (E)? • Antibiotics alone with discharge is not appropriate management • While "antibiotic-first" strategy exists for uncomplicated appendicitis, requires careful patient selection and inpatient monitoring Surgery: Laparoscopic appendectomy is preferred — lower wound infection rate, faster recovery.

stem:
A 68-year-old man presents with 2 days of progressive abdominal distension, crampy abdominal pain, and vomiting. He has not had a bowel movement 
or passed flatus for 36 hours. His surgical history includes open appendectomy 30 years ago and cholecystectomy 10 years ago. 
On examination, temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 118/72 mm Hg, pulse is 94/min. Abdomen is distended with high-pitched bowel sounds 
and mild diffuse tenderness without peritoneal signs. There is a well-healed RLQ scar. 
Abdominal X-ray shows multiple dilated loops of small bowel (up to 5 cm) with air-fluid levels in a stepladder pattern. No colonic gas is seen. No free air. 
Laboratory studies show WBC 11,200/µL, BUN 28 mg/dL, and lactate 1.4 mmol/L.

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?

options.text: Nasogastric tube decompression, IV fluids, and NPO
options.label: C

explanation: This patient has small bowel obstruction (SBO), most likely due to adhesions from prior abdominal surgery. Differentiating SBO from LBO: Feature SBO LBO Pain Crampy, periumbilical Crampy, lower abdominal Vomiting Early, prominent Late, may be feculent Distension Moderate Marked Obstipation Later Earlier X-ray Dilated small bowel, air-fluid levels Dilated colon, "cut-off" sign Common causes Adhesions (most common), hernia Colon cancer, diverticulitis, volvulus This patient has SBO: • Previous abdominal surgeries → adhesions (#1 cause of SBO) • Dilated small bowel with air-fluid levels on X-ray • No colonic gas (complete or near-complete obstruction) • Vomiting prominent Management of uncomplicated/partial SBO: Step Intervention 1 NPO (bowel rest) 2 Nasogastric tube (decompression, relieves vomiting) 3 IV fluid resuscitation (third-spacing causes dehydration) 4 Foley catheter (monitor urine output) 5 Serial abdominal exams 6 Correct electrolytes This conservative "drip and suck" approach resolves 65–80% of adhesive SBO without surgery. When is surgery indicated (emergently)? • Peritoneal signs (rebound, guarding) — bowel compromise • Fever, tachycardia, leukocytosis (significant) — strangulation • Elevated lactate — ischemia • Closed-loop obstruction • Failure to improve with conservative management (24–72 hours) • Complete obstruction that doesn't resolve This patient lacks emergent surgical indications: • No peritoneal signs • Mild tachycardia, minimal leukocytosis • Normal lactate Why not (A)? • No signs of strangulation or peritonitis • Surgery reserved for complicated SBO or failed conservative management Why not (B)? • Colonoscopy is for LBO (e.g., sigmoid volvulus decompression) • Not useful for SBO Why not (D)? • Water-soluble contrast (Gastrografin) can be used but is given orally/via NGT in SBO (not enema) • Therapeutic and diagnostic — appearance of contrast in colon within 24 hours predicts resolution Why not (E)? • Oral prep contraindicated in bowel obstruction

stem:
A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe lower back and abdominal pain that began 45 minutes ago. He 
has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and 50-pack-year smoking history. He quit smoking 5 years ago. 
On examination, he is pale, diaphoretic, and appears to be in severe distress. Blood pressure is 78/52 mm Hg, pulse is 124/min and weak. Abdomen is 
distended with a pulsatile mass palpable in the periumbilical region. Femoral pulses are weak bilaterally. 
Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

options.text: IV fluids to stabilize blood pressure before imaging
options.label: D

options.text: Obtain type and crossmatch, then await hemodynamic stability
options.label: E

explanation: This patient has ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (rAAA) — a surgical emergency with mortality approaching 50% even with treatment, and >80% without. Classic triad of ruptured AAA: 1. Sudden severe abdominal or back pain 2. Hypotension 3. Pulsatile abdominal mass This patient has all three features — the diagnosis is clinical. Management of hemodynamically UNSTABLE rAAA: Priority Action 1 Immediate transfer to OR for surgical repair 2 Permissive hypotension (target SBP ~70–80, avoid aggressive fluid resuscitation) 3 Type and crossmatch, activate massive transfusion protocol 4 Do NOT delay for imaging if diagnosis is clear Why immediate surgery without imaging? • In unstable patients with classic triad, imaging delays definitive treatment • Every minute without repair increases mortality • Diagnosis is clinical; imaging may cause death in unstable patients When is imaging appropriate? • Hemodynamically STABLE patients with suspected AAA → CT angiography • Screens for extent of aneurysm, involvement of renal/iliac arteries • Plans surgical or endovascular approach Why permissive hypotension? • Aggressive IV fluids can: • Dislodge tamponading clot • Dilute clotting factors • Increase hemorrhage • Maintain "just enough" pressure for end-organ perfusion Why not (A)? • CT delays surgery in unstable patient • Appropriate only if hemodynamically stable Why not (C)? • Bedside ultrasound can confirm AAA but should not delay OR • In this case, clinical diagnosis is clear Why not (D)? • Avoid aggressive fluid resuscitation — permissive hypotension preferred • Proceed directly to OR Why not (E)? • Type and crossmatch should be drawn but don't wait for stability — this patient may never stabilize without surgery Repair options: • Open surgical repair (traditional) • Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) — increasingly used even for rupture in selected patients Screening recommendation (USPSTF): • One-time abdominal ultrasound for men aged 65–75 who have ever smoked

stem:
An 18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department with 3 days of watery diarrhea (8–10 episodes daily) and vomiting. His mother reports he 
has been increasingly lethargic and has had decreased urine output for the past 24 hours. 
On examination, temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), heart rate is 156/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 85/50 mm Hg. Weight is 10 kg 
(baseline 11 kg). He is lethargic but responds to stimuli. Eyes are sunken with absent tears. Mucous membranes are dry. Capillary refill is 4 seconds. Skin 
turgor is decreased with tenting.

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial fluid management?

options.text: Oral rehydration solution 50 mL/kg over 4 hours
options.label: A

options.text: IV 0.9% normal saline 20 mL/kg bolus, reassess, repeat as needed
options.label: C

options.text: IV D5 0.45% normal saline at maintenance rate
options.label: D

explanation: This child has severe dehydration requiring IV fluid resuscitation. Dehydration severity assessment: Feature Mild (3–5%) Moderate (6–9%) Severe (≥10%) Mental status Alert Irritable/lethargic Lethargic/obtunded Thirst Slight Moderate Drinks poorly Heart rate Normal Increased Markedly increased Blood pressure Normal Normal/orthostatic Hypotension Tears Present Decreased Absent Eyes Normal Slightly sunken Deeply sunken Mucous membranes Moist Dry Parched Capillary refill <2 sec 2–3 sec >3 sec Skin turgor Normal Decreased Tenting Urine output Decreased Oliguria Anuria This child has SEVERE dehydration (≥10%): • 9% weight loss (11 kg → 10 kg) • Lethargic • Absent tears • Sunken eyes • Capillary refill 4 seconds • Tenting • Hypotension for age • Tachycardia Fluid management by severity: Severity Management Mild ORS 50 mL/kg over 4 hours Moderate ORS 100 mL/kg over 4 hours (consider IV if can't tolerate PO) Severe IV bolus 20 mL/kg NS (isotonic), reassess, repeat up to 3 boluses Why NS 20 mL/kg bolus? • Isotonic fluid expands intravascular volume • 20 mL/kg is safe initial dose • Reassess after each bolus (HR, BP, capillary refill, mental status) • May need 2–3 boluses for severe dehydration • After stabilization → calculate deficit + maintenance Why not (A)? • Oral rehydration inappropriate for severe dehydration with lethargy • Risk of aspiration, inadequate absorption Why not (B)? • 200 mL/kg at once is excessive and dangerous • Can cause fluid overload, pulmonary edema Why not (D)? • Hypotonic maintenance fluid inappropriate for resuscitation • Does not adequately expand intravascular volume • D5 0.45% NS used for maintenance after resuscitation Why not (E)? • Hypertonic saline for symptomatic hyponatremia only • Not indicated for routine dehydration After stabilization: • Calculate deficit (10% of body weight = 1000 mL) • Replace deficit over 24–48 hours plus maintenance • Replace ongoing losses

stem:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with 6 days of high fever (up to 40°C/104°F) that has not responded to acetaminophen. His mother reports he 
has been increasingly irritable. Over the past few days, she noticed redness in both eyes without discharge, cracked red lips, and a rash on his trunk. 
On examination, temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), heart rate is 132/min. He is irritable but consolable. He has bilateral conjunctival injection without 
exudate. Lips are erythematous and cracked; tongue appears red with prominent papillae ("strawberry tongue"). There is a polymorphous maculopapular 
rash on his trunk. Bilateral cervical lymph nodes are palpable (largest 1.8 cm). Hands are edematous with erythema of the palms. 
Laboratory studies show WBC 18,400/µL, hemoglobin 10.8 g/dL, platelets 486,000/µL, ESR 82 mm/hr, CRP 12 mg/dL, and albumin 2.8 g/dL.

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?

options.text: IV antibiotics for presumed scarlet fever
options.label: A

options.text: High-dose aspirin and supportive care only
options.label: B

explanation: This patient meets criteria for Kawasaki disease (KD), a medium-vessel vasculitis affecting children, primarily dangerous for its cardiac complications (coronary artery aneurysms). Diagnostic criteria (classic KD): Fever ≥5 days PLUS ≥4 of 5: 1. Bilateral conjunctival injection (non-exudative) ✓ 2. Oral mucosal changes (strawberry tongue, cracked lips) ✓ 3. Polymorphous rash ✓ 4. Extremity changes (edema, erythema, later desquamation) ✓ 5. Cervical lymphadenopathy (≥1.5 cm, usually unilateral) ✓ This patient: 6 days of fever + 5/5 criteria = CLASSIC KAWASAKI DISEASE Laboratory findings supporting KD: • Leukocytosis • Anemia (normocytic) • Thrombocytosis (peaks in week 2–3) • Elevated ESR/CRP • Hypoalbuminemia • Elevated transaminases • Sterile pyuria may be present Treatment — CRITICAL to start within 10 days of fever onset: Component Details Purpose IVIG 2 g/kg single infusion Reduces coronary aneurysm risk from 25% → <5% Aspirin (high-dose) 80–100 mg/kg/day divided q6h Anti-inflammatory Aspirin (low-dose) 3–5 mg/kg/day after fever resolves Antiplatelet for 6–8 weeks Why IVIG + aspirin? • IVIG dramatically reduces coronary artery aneurysm development • Treatment within 10 days of fever onset is most effective • Aspirin alone is inadequate Why not (A)? • KD is not bacterial; antibiotics ineffective • Can resemble scarlet fever but conjunctivitis is not a feature of scarlet fever • Scarlet fever has sandpaper rash, not polymorphous Why not (B)? • Aspirin alone does not prevent coronary aneurysms • IVIG is essential Why not (D)? • Corticosteroids reserved for IVIG-refractory KD • Not first-line **

stem:
A 58-year-old man with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation presents for follow-up. Despite optimal doses of metoprolol and flecainide, he continues to have symptomatic episodes 2-3 times monthly with palpitations and fatigue that significantly affect his quality of life. Echocardiogram shows normal LV function and left atrial size of 4.2 cm. His CHA₂DS₂-VASc score is 1.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation: Catheter ablation is appropriate for patients with symptomatic AFib refractory to at least one antiarrhythmic drug (AAD) or in patients who prefer ablation over long-term AAD therapy. This patient has failed flecainide and continues to have quality-of-life-limiting symptoms. His preserved LV function and moderately sized left atrium make him a good ablation candidate. Amiodarone (A) could be tried but has significant long-term toxicity. Rate control alone (E) is inappropriate given his symptomatic episodes despite adequate rate control.

stem:
A 67-year-old woman with newly diagnosed HFrEF (EF 30%) is admitted for acute decompensated heart failure with dyspnea at rest and bilateral lower extremity edema. She is started on IV furosemide with good urine output. On hospital day 2, she still has 2+ peripheral edema, JVP of 12 cm, and bibasilar crackles.
